title: Why are there resourceless champions?
body:
I'm not complaining about Garen, Riven, or Katarina because I lost to them recently. In fact, I don't even get a chance to play against them because  they are banned at my elo.
I'm just curious, in terms of design, why there are resourceless champions. What's the idea behind creating a champion who doesn't have to manage resources?

replies.body:
By concept, different resources have different effects on champions.

Mana for example is a resource amazing at doing a shitton of things at once, sometimes in a continuous stream. Burst mages for example are the prime definition of this as they can often throw at least some spell at a solid pace for long periods of time before dropping their entire kit on the enemy's head. It also provides early game gating and late game freedom, as early game you may have to consistently worry about your mana, but by the later stages of the game you quite frankly do not care about it anymore.

Energy is a resource that, if you are careful about, acts essentially resourceless. You can not fire large amounts of your kit consecutively like a mana user can, but you can drop an entire rotation of spells on the enemy's head after pacing your abilities in a way that your fast energy regen kicks in over time. Energy lacks the ability to build out of this restriction however, so if an energy based kit is designed to max out on energy with only 2 rotations of the champ's spells, you're not going to ever get around it no matter how you build.

Cooldowns, finally, have two significant weaknesses depending on how the champion is built. If it's a champion like Garen who is restricted by longass cooldowns, or on the opposite end of the spectrum Katarina with weak ass spells, resourceless champs are often balanced around the fact that they perform subpar to energy and mana in very specific matchups. Katarina for example is straight up weaker than Talon in many raw damage scenarios if you consider that her ult is easily interrupted and Talon can rely on multiple auto attacks with far more power than the former.

The reason why resourceless champions exist is to put a different spin on a kit than energy or mana could allow. Yasuo's design quite frankly is impossible with mana or energy because his Qs are essentially auto attacks and as his main combat skill damn near mandatory towards his damage potential. Wind Wall was designed as a reactive skill and therefore giving mana or energy is nothing more than a damning limit to using the ability in emergency situations. And don't even get started on trying to make his E function off a resource.

Most champions that use health as a resource function most similarly to mana users, since they are generally gated pretty hard early on and then as the game progresses they are less and less limited by their costs until they are functionally cooldown based.

They are different from mana users because their early game risk isn't based around not having the resource to cast abilities, but also not having health to survive a trade. Health users are generally able to scale harder in terms of combined durability and damage output than most other champs with similar kits (i.e. Vlad deals comparable damage to many other late game mages, but also becomes much more durable than almost any other true mage in the game, or Mundo becomes tankier than most tanks, but is still allowed a really impressive amount of damage for being near impossible to kill).

Because you're thinking of resources wrong. They don't exist so that champs 'have something to manage', they are there purely because designers want certain champs to play a certain way. 

Did designers intend for you to spam the shit out of powerful spells mid-late game, but not want you to be a lane bully? You get mana.

Did designers want for you to be able to itemize for increased spell spam via cdr/mana/mana regen, but also don't want you to run out of mana in lane? You get energy.

Did designers want you to spam spells literally whenever you find an opportunity where it makes sense to, with the desire to have you be limited in some other way such as damage, cooldowns, or squishyness while being melee? You get 'no resource'.

Did designers want you to be super aggressive and make you weaker when you aren't being aggressive while also never running out of mana? You get rage.

Did designers want you to carefully balance your ability rotations to optimize damage with a significant risk for over spamming, without running out of mana? You get heat.

Did designers want you to be constantly on the move, spamming skills and dashing around, while being vulnerable if you ever stop moving, and without worrying about mana because you need to spam constantly to survive? You get flow.

Etc.

It's not about how 'fair it is' for one champ to have mana and another champ to have energy/fury/rage/heat/no resource. It's about how the designers want the champion to play. Lux has long cds and mana because she has the longest range of almost any champion and would bully everyone in lane otherwise - and she's not intended to be a lane bully. Renekton is intended to be a lane bully, so he uses no mana and in fact gets stronger specifically by pushing lane. Zed has energy because he would be worthless mid against any ranged champions as a melee squishy if he went oom from using shadows and shurikens to farm, but they also want him to only be able to assassinate one person lategame before running out of resources. Katarina has no resource because he entire kit is designed around being useless she can start resetting her skills and going on a reset spree - and running oom when her time finaly comes to shine would be dumb on to of her shitty lane phase as a melee with low damage, high cooldown skills and an interuptable point blank ult.

Maybe I'm drawing implications far deeper than intended, but you're saying that being manaless should take up more of a kit's power than it currently does.

The thing is that resourceless champions *appear* stronger because of the lack of a gating mechanism. Pretty much anything can seem overwhelming if it literally never stops coming back. Still, all comparable manaless vs. mana-based champions I've seen are, in the most perfect and ideal scenarios, on equal footing, and it takes *a hell of a lot more effort* for manaless champions to keep up.

If more power was shaved from manaless champions, they would pretty much lose mid-game and late-game relevance if they didn't shut down their laning opponent and get a decent lead against the rest of the enemy team.

1) Yes, Riven has a lot of the same weaknesses that every melee champion has. The difference is that *her kit doesn't actually mitigate those weaknesses.* In any way. She lacks real sustain and defense so she can have a shield that scales *very poorly* on AD.

1 point of HP per 1 point of AD is worth a little less than 2.7 gold worth of HP for every point of AD. She has 300 AD? Congratulations, when her shield is up, she has an extra 810 gold worth of HP with no resistances to actually make that HP useful. And her shield doesn't stay up in extended fights.

"She can overcome her lack of sustain with Lifesteal." **So can every melee champion in the game, but covering for a weakness doesn't mean it isn't a weakness.**

2) "Let's just say you have Zed mid vs. Orianna."

Okay, let's say you have Ahri mid vs. Orianna. Let's say you have Leblanc mid vs. Orianna. Let's say you have Talon mid vs. Orianna. *What happens in all of those situations?*

Oh, that's right, **they're Assassins. They quite literally exist to kill solo targets, which is why they're taken mid-lane against basic Mages.**

Yes, Zed mid has an advantage against Orianna, *but that has far less to do with him being manaless, and far more to do with him being specifically designed to ruin her day, as is any assassin.* The fact that he's manaless makes it *worse,* yes. The fact that Orianna got nerfed to shit also makes it worse.
